results.title: Bolgene
results.brief_description: Two young men who have been boyhood friends for years are taking their regular holiday together on a Scandanavian island. However, with approaching adulthood, the sexual tensions in their relationships begin to emerge. This is a serious and beautifully crafted story about adolescence and innocence, and the inevitability of change. By concentrating on the physicality and intimacy of the two male bodies in space, Mosvold creates a haunting, resonating work.

results.title: Expectant spaces
results.brief_description: A commissioned Public Imaging project by Melbourne cinematographer, Ben Speth. His extraordinary, meditative work manifests as a mysterious visual documentation of volume, light and time in deserted urban spaces. A sense of expectancy emerges through his still, ghostly and enigmatic images of spaces of waiting or anticipation - hospital emergency rooms, bus shelters, classrooms, dental waiting rooms, car parks.

results.title: Saturn's return
results.creator_credit: Wenona Byrne, Christos Tsiolkas and Helen Pankhurst
results.brief_description: ‘Saturn’s return’ is part of an SBS commissioned series called ‘Hybrid Life’, which explores the experience of second and third generation migrants. Barney and his lover Dimi set out on a road trip to visit Barney’s father who is dying of AIDS and has decided to end his life. Based on a short story by Christos Tsiolkas and directed by Wenona Byrne, the film uses the road movie journey as a means to travel through Australia’s chequered history, while the two lovers confront their families turbulent past.

results.title: Small treasures
results.brief_description: Based on autobiographical experience, Small Treasures is about the still birth of a child. Written in a diary form, it follows an ordinary pregnancy through to its devastating conclusion. Beautifully made and hand coloured this film won best short at the Venice Film Festival.

results.title: Blue
results.creator_credit: Curtis Wehrfritz, Bruce McDonald and Don McKellar
results.brief_description: Canadian horror director David Cronenberg puts in an impressive performance as a bored carpert factory executive whose daily routine involves minor flirtations with his secretary and cronic masturbation in the privacy of his office. This explicit and ultimately melancholy tale of pornography and loneliness is intercut with a 1960s era stag loop called ‘The bellboy and the bored housewife’ and features the film’s star reminiscing about her experiences in the sex trade.

results.title: And the lighthouse made three
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: A plasticene animated film about a lonely lighthouse, a craggy old lighthouse keeper and a mysterious dark figure that moves in the fog. A delightful song ends this tale of unrequited love.

results.title: Phantom
results.brief_description: This video work is a mysterious, ghostly geography of cinematic shadows. Silhouettes that never quite take shape shift and glide across the screen, anaemic figures, seen in the negative, forced to wander between narratives restlessly but caught in a loop. These remnants from faint memories of filmic melodrama are a living dead confined to a space they cannot leave. They are the secret that lies between stories.

results.title: Tomatoes for Troops
results.creator_credit: Bob Harper, Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture. Film Unit and Jack Keane
results.brief_description:
This film, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, is an example of propaganda for the war effort, encouraging farmers to grow tomatoes for the armed forces during the Second World War. The film includes footage of soldiers on the Kokoda Trail, and outlines the importance of vegetables for the armed forces in combat overseas.

The film takes the viewer through the stages of tomato production on a mass scale, showing the process of collecting, disinfecting and washing seeds; cultivating and fertilising the soil; planting the seedlings and maximising growth. The film then outlines common diseases and pests that threaten the healthy growth of tomato plants, such as spotted wilt, tomato moths and weevils, along with preventative measures to mitigate these risks.

Finally, the film shows the industrial-scale quality assessment and canning of tomatoes in a factory. The final product, shown in the hands of an active soldier, is a can of SPC peeled tomatoes.

results.title: Project the right image
results.brief_description:
English production, NOT made by the Department of Agriculture.

Details hot to and how not to project a 16mm film using a social church gathering as the backdrop. Stars a bumbling projectionist and a priest who first do everything the wrong way and then do everything the correct way.

Comical (in a daggy way) throughout with good use of slapstick humour. Also contains an amusing, very dry voiceover.
